I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help improve institutional 
capacity and service delivery for state-owned enterprises (SOEs) and in sectors and economies 
where SOEs are prominent. In response to Asian Development Bank (ADB) developing member 
country (DMC) demand, the TA will be coordinated with ADB operations departments and develop 
SOE diagnostics, SOE knowledge and tools, and institutional capacity for SOE oversight and 
reform.  
 
2.  The TA is aligned with ADB Strategy 2030 and the draft operational plan for operational 
priority 6 on strengthening governance and institutional capacity in DMCs.1 It builds on the 
meetings and findings of the SOE Working Group, which included high level representation from 
across ADB and whose acting secretariat is the Governance Thematic Group (SDTC-GOV) of the 
Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC). ADB is launching the TA to 
support its operational work with SOEs and implement ADB Strategy 2030, which emphasizes 
SOE reforms and internal governance to improve access to capital and service delivery. The TA 
is included in SDCC’s 2019 results-based work plan.2 
  
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  SOEs have long played an important role in economic development in Asia and the Pacific. 
Especially prominent in energy, transportation, and finance, SOEs also include major enterprises 
in mining, manufacturing, food distribution, and other industries. Their share of gross domestic 
product in Asian economies generally ranges from an estimated 20%–40%. Beyond their impact 
on service delivery and productivity in key industries, SOEs can be an important source of both 
government revenues and liabilities.3 SOE governance and performance can ultimately influence 
the achievement of several sustainable development goals.4 
  
4.  Governments sometimes created SOEs in areas like natural monopolies, where they felt 
the government should retain control. In many cases, governments used SOEs to launch new 
industries or expand existing ones, even when, historically, the private sector had developed 
these industries in more advanced economies. Across Asia and the Pacific, SOEs still play a 
prominent role in operating and expanding much needed infrastructure.  
 
5.  Unfortunately, in too many Asian and Pacific economies, poorly performing SOE sectors 
effectively hinder sustainable development. Several years of reform have not addressed the 
causes of this core problem: vulnerability to political interference and corruption; an unlevel 
playing field with the private sector; and reduced SOE productivity due to soft budget constraints, 
poor internal and sector governance, and, crucially, little or no real accountability combined with 
multiple and conflicting objectives. In addition, SOEs may have hidden and contingent liabilities 
for the national budget.   
                                                
1  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila; 
and ADB. Strategy 2030 Operational Plans for Priority 6: Strengthening Governance and Institutional Capacity, 
2019–2024 (Draft). Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 22 July 2019. 
3  International Monetary Fund. 2018. Fiscal Monitor Reports: Managing Public Wealth. Washington, D.C.; and World

4  These include Sustainable Development Goals 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions; 6: Clean Water and

and Communities.

2 
6.  Underlying these challenges are the root failures of SOE oversight and governance: 
systematic opacity and a deep resistance to useful disclosure; poorly designed and unfunded 
policy  mandates;  and  legal  and  regulatory  regimes  that  are  ambiguous,  incomplete,  and 
unnecessarily distinct from the private sector. Most importantly, no part of the government has 
real responsibility for SOE performance or is held accountable for it. The nature of SOEs 
themselves, the quality of management, and how the state acts as owner of assets drive these 
underlying causes and the resulting negative effects.5 These challenges are compounded by the 
politically sensitive nature of SOEs and potential reforms.  
  
7.  ADB has long worked to address these challenges in its engagements with SOEs. ADB 
Strategy 2030 and the forthcoming operational plan on strengthening governance and institutional 
capacity emphasize that this engagement should continue and become more effective.6 
 
8.  However, according to a 2018 Independent Evaluation report, supported reforms tended 
to be piecemeal and few addressed how the state acts as an owner of assets and who carries 
out that role(s) in the state administration.7 The Management response to the report supported 
the recommendations for ADB to strengthen operations dealing with SOE reforms.8  
 
9.  ADB’s approach to SOE reform is consistent with international experience. For decades, 
countries around the world made repeated reforms to SOEs. In most countries, these reforms did 
not sufficiently address root causes and their results were often disappointing. With only partial 
reforms, countries still experienced limited private sector development; poor delivery of and 
limited investments in energy, transportation, finance, and other key areas; adverse budgetary 
impacts; and heightened vulnerability to economic shocks.  
 
10.  After 2000, a growing number of countries focused reforms on how the state carried out 
its ownership functions. The exercise of these functions was often centralized, sometimes under 
the ministry of finance or industry, but increasingly in specialized holding companies or equivalent 
entities. In many instances, these reforms led to greater market contestability as barriers to entry 
were  reduced  and  competition  led  to  the  dismantling  or  significant  downsizing  of  SOEs, 
particularly in manufacturing and services. More broadly, these reforms increased commercial 
orientation, expected returns on capital and investment, transparency, and improved high-level 
decision-making, board appointment, and other aspects of corporate governance. Countries often 
pursued these reforms in conjunction with wider reforms to SOE performance management, 
sector governance,  subsidies,  public  service  obligations,  and  public financial  management. 
Efforts to ensure a level playing field with the private sector often become more effective, as did 
ongoing corporatization, restructuring, and privatization.9 
 
11.  Some economies in Asia and the Pacific led these reforms, which have now spread to 
others. When SOE governance is more advanced, substantial scope typically remains for further 
improvement to help access capital markets, increase infrastructure finance and service delivery, 
and  improve  reporting on  and  increased  consideration  of  wider  environmental,  social,  and 
governance issues.

Owned Enterprises: A Survey of OECD Countries. Paris.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: service delivery by SOEs strengthened.10 The TA will 
have the following outcome: improvement of SOE governance and oversight in selected DMCs 
supported.11 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
13.  The TA will help implement ADB Strategy 2030’s call for better SOE governance and other 
SOE reform. It will build on international standards and good practice as well as the ADB’s own 
extensive experience with SOEs. The ultimate goal of SOE reforms would be better service 
delivery and improved operational efficiency. The TA will focus on DMCs with the will for SOE 
reform and coordinate closely with ADB operations departments. The TA will provide knowledge, 
knowledge-sharing, and tools grounded in the realities and opportunities for SOE reform in Asia 
and the Pacific. It will begin a series of focused diagnostics to identify and correct the root causes 
of SOE failure. In conjunction with ADB operations and the knowledge building and diagnostic 
components, the TA will support focused institutional capacity development.  
 
14.  Specific areas of focus for SOE diagnostics and knowledge and institutional capacity 
development  will  include  fiscal  linkages,  sector  governance  and  competition,  and  internal 
governance and transparency. Crucially, this TA will seek to better understand and improve how 
DMCs measure SOE performance, hold SOEs accountable for that performance, and make other 
major decisions in SOEs. Findings from this work will feed into country partnership strategies and 
operational work.  
 
15.  The TA will also improve SOE performance by supporting corporatization, equitization, 
shedding non-core assets, and appropriate private sector engagement. These reforms can help 
transition an SOE to direct and non-sovereign borrowing, and ultimately, on the strength of its 
balance sheet, to the financial markets, but this transition also depends on strong government 
ownership of the reforms, on the governance of the SOE, its economic fundamentals, and the 
market(s) it is operating in. The main outputs of the TA are listed below.12 
 
16.  Output 1: State-owned enterprise diagnostics prepared. The TA will support national, 
sector, and enterprise level diagnostics that will benchmark SOE governance and oversight 
against well-established international standards, including those issued by the Organisation for 
Economic Co-operation and Development and the World Bank.13 The goal will be to find major 
gaps and risk areas and develop appropriate solutions. The TA will conduct diagnostics in at least 
two DMCs based on operational priorities and the input of the SOE Working Group. Their findings 
will inform tools developed under output 2 and feed into capacity development under output 3.  
   
                                                
10 Footnote 1. 
11 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
12  Based on consultations with operations departments and DMCs, activities under the TA include: (i) a diagnostic and 
related capacity development on corporate governance implementation in the 50 largest SOEs in Uzbekistan; (ii) 
capacity development under a road map for SOE reform that is currently being drafted in Maldives; (iii) policy 
development to better insure port assets against natural disasters in Samoa, in coordination with an ADB port project; 
and (iv) a governance brief and case studies for use in DMCs and ADB to help increase understanding of best 
approaches to SOE reform. 
13 OECD. 2015. OECD Guidelines on Corporate Governance of State-Owned Enterprises. Paris; and World Bank.

4 
17.  Output 2: State-owned enterprise knowledge and tools developed. The TA will help 
publish policy-relevant guidance on SOE reform. The TA will also support the participation of 
government officials who oversee SOEs and SOE leadership in relevant regional and international 
events, including as part of their engagement with ADB operational work and under output 3. In 
addition, the TA will develop diagnostic tools, case studies, and other relevant training materials 
for outputs 1 and 3. The TA will support an overview of SOE governance and related challenges 
in Asia and the Pacific. 
 
18.  Output 3: Capacity development for state-owned enterprise oversight and reform 
supported. The TA will provide guidance on relevant policy and regulation and help train those 
in ownership and oversight entities and in leadership and vigilance positions in SOEs. This 
capacity development will build on international good practice, and when possible build on 
diagnostics. The TA will help develop capacity in at least three DMCs, in close coordination with 
ADB operations departments. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  ADB will administer the TA with SDTC-GOV as the executing and implementing agency. 
SDTC-GOV will report to the SOE Working Group on TA progress and consult with relevant sector 
and  thematic  groups  during  implementation.  It  will  work  and  coordinate  with  operations 
departments to seek concurrence from selected DMCs for country-level activities. It will select, 
supervise, and evaluate consultants, organize workshops, and provide staff to act as resource 
persons in workshops.

22.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.14 The TA will require 17 person-months of international and 9 person-months of 
national consultant inputs with expertise in SOE policy, governance, operations, and related 
sectoral, private finance, and public finance expertise. ADB will recruit individual consultants for 
outputs 1–3, and a national consulting firm for output 3 using consultants’ qualification selection, 
as provided for in the staff instructions for ADB Administered Consulting Services for very small 
assignments which do not exceed $200,000. SDTC-GOV will manage all consultants unless 
otherwise agreed with operations departments. Where appropriate, output-based contracts will 
be considered for administrative efficiency and for a simplified disbursement process. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening State-Owned Enterprise Accountability and Performance, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.
